comment.text: Works ok for me ... Ryzen 7 2700/Radeon 5600XT
No issues spotted on 5900X + RX7900 XTX, regression run passed
Default & performance tests pass (KVM)
Default & performance tests pass (KVM)

Works on Acer Aspire Intel® Core™ i7-3632QM CPU @ 2.20GHz Memory: 15.4 GiB of RAM Graphics Processor: Mesa DRI Intel® HD Graphics 4000. wi-fi: Qualcomm Atheros AR9485 Wireless Network Adapter vendor: Lite-On driver: ath9k v: kernel pcie: speed: 2.5 GT/s lanes: 1 Passed ALL kernel regression tests.

Works on KVM, EFI firmware:

```
type arch="x86_64" machine="pc-q35-6.2"
cpu mode="host-passthrough"
Processors: Intel® Core™ i7-3632QM CPU @ 2.20GHz
```

`./runtests.sh` PASS with kernel-6.1.9-200.fc37.x86_64 within a kvm/qemu VM (KDE spin, up to date with all testing repos enabled) on a AMD Ryzen 6000 mobile series host. No third party modules (tainted = 0).

I tested the VM some minutes with average activities, works fine so far. No errors/issues when using it.

Works for me.. The enabled Default and Performance tests pass OK.

Ryzen5 5600g/AMDGPU, 400 Series Chipset (Legacy BIOS) SSD's > RAID1 Work Station, running Plasma DE from Zawertun's COPR.

Default and Performance tests passed. Intel NUC6i5SYK, Intel Core i5-6260U × 4, Mesa Intel Iris Graphics 540 (SKL GT3).

Default and Performance tests passed. Dell XPS 13 9350, Intel Core i7-6560U × 4, Mesa Intel Iris Graphics 540 (SKL GT3). 
Dell Laptop working fine in heavy use.
Default and Performance tests passed on esxi 6.7
This update finally fixed DisplayPort MST on amdgpu. Absolute shitshow how Fedora shipped a kernel update to 6.1.x that knowingly breaks external display output for many AMD users in the first place.
Works for me.
Seems to work fine on bare-metal HP Z440, AMD RX570 with UEFI. No issues to report so far and kernel regression tests both PASS.
Working in a VirtualBox VM just fine.

Working fine here.

Intel NUC i7 NUC11PAH 1 x 11th Gen Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-1165G7 @ 2.80GHz
Intel Corporation TigerLake-LP GT2 [Iris Xe Graphics] (rev 01)

bugs.title: CVE-2023-0597 kernel: x86/mm: Randomize per-cpu entry area

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2023-0597 kernel: x86/mm: Randomize per-cpu entry area

long_desc.thetext:
A flaw possibility of memory leak in the Linux Kernel found.
There is no randomization of the exception stacks happening at all including boot-time randomization. These exception
stacks are mapped into the kernel at the same virtual address every time.
The exception stack(s) is a particularly easy target because its location can be computed based solely on CPU index and kernel version.
For the CPU-entry-area, the piece of per-cpu data that is mapped into the userspace page-tables for KPTI is not subject to any randomization (irrespective of KASLR settings). The KASLR-style randomization isn't enough, because attacker probably could discover even the task stacks at least on X86 systems without KPTI with something like the prefetch timing side channel that can test for PTE existence (see reference to the prefetch.pdf).
Sure, the system call stack is randomized, but that randomization happens after kernel entry and after pt_regs have been saved. It would be good if at least in the worst-case scenario of an attack against the kernel, an attacker wouldn't know fixed addresses where zeroes / kernel text pointers / other known values are stored.
As result, straight forward randomization scheme that avoids duplicates to spread the existing CPUs over the available space suggested (see reference to the patch).

References:
https://gruss.cc/files/prefetch.pdf
https://lore.kernel.org/lkml/Yz%2FmfJ1gjgshF19t@hirez.programming.kicks-ass.net/
https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/torvalds/linux.git/commit/arch/x86/mm/cpu_entry_area.c?h=v6.2-rc6&id=97e3d26b5e5f371b3ee223d94dd123e6c442ba80

This is an automatically created tracking bug!  It was created to ensure
that one or more security vulnerabilities are fixed in affected versions
of fedora-all.

For comments that are specific to the vulnerability please use bugs filed
against the "Security Response" product referenced in the "Blocks" field.

For more information see:
http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Security/TrackingBugs

When submitting as an update, use the fedpkg template provided in the next
comment(s).  This will include the bug IDs of this tracking bug as well as
the relevant top-level CVE bugs.

Please also mention the CVE IDs being fixed in the RPM changelog and the
fedpkg commit message.

NOTE: this issue affects multiple supported versions of Fedora. While only
one tracking bug has been filed, please correct all affected versions at
the same time.  If you need to fix the versions independent of each other,
you may clone this bug as appropriate.

Reproducers, if any, will remain confidential and never be made public, unless done so by the security team.

Use the following template to for the 'fedpkg update' request to submit an
update for this issue as it contains the top-level parent bug(s) as well as
this tracking bug.  This will ensure that all associated bugs get updated
when new packages are pushed to stable.

=====

# bugfix, security, enhancement, newpackage (required)
type=security

# low, medium, high, urgent (required)
severity=medium

# testing, stable
request=testing

# Bug numbers: 1234,9876
bugs=2165926,2165927

# Description of your update
notes=Security fix for [PUT CVEs HERE]

# Enable request automation based on the stable/unstable karma thresholds
autokarma=True
stable_karma=3
unstable_karma=-3

# Automatically close bugs when this marked as stable
close_bugs=True

# Suggest that users restart after update
suggest_reboot=False

======

Additionally, you may opt to use the bodhi web interface to submit updates:

https://bodhi.fedoraproject.org/updates/new
FEDORA-2023-4006357f7e has been submitted as an update to Fedora 37. https://bodhi.fedoraproject.org/updates/FEDORA-2023-4006357f7e
FEDORA-2023-c9ab30c8e3 has been submitted as an update to Fedora 36. https://bodhi.fedoraproject.org/updates/FEDORA-2023-c9ab30c8e3

FEDORA-2023-c9ab30c8e3 has been pushed to the Fedora 36 testing repository.
Soon you'll be able to install the update with the following command:
`sudo dnf upgrade --enablerepo=updates-testing --refresh --advisory=FEDORA-2023-c9ab30c8e3`
You can provide feedback for this update here: https://bodhi.fedoraproject.org/updates/FEDORA-2023-c9ab30c8e3

See also https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/QA:Updates_Testing for more information on how to test updates.

FEDORA-2023-4006357f7e has been pushed to the Fedora 37 testing repository.
Soon you'll be able to install the update with the following command:
`sudo dnf upgrade --enablerepo=updates-testing --refresh --advisory=FEDORA-2023-4006357f7e`
You can provide feedback for this update here: https://bodhi.fedoraproject.org/updates/FEDORA-2023-4006357f7e

See also https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/QA:Updates_Testing for more information on how to test updates.

If problem still persists, please make note of it in this bug report.

If problem still persists, please make note of it in this bug report.
